item.title: Biodiversity Conservation
item.description: We are working on designing and implement biodiversity in some places.

item.title: Time series analysis in R
item.description:
It is about how to analyze time series using R package ts, which can analyze and predict.

# 首先建立一个模拟的向量可以表示真实世界的时间序列数据过程。比如从1到100，但具有随机噪音
set.seed(123)
t <- seq(from = 1, to = 100, by = 1) + 10 + rnorm(100, sd = 7)
plot(t)

# 使用args函数看函数的参数设置
args(ts)
## function (data = NA, start = 1, end = numeric(), frequency = 1, 
##     deltat = 1, ts.eps = getOption("ts.eps"), class = if (nseries > 
##         1) c("mts", "ts", "matrix") else "ts", names = if (!is.null(dimnames(data))) colnames(data) else paste("Series", 
##         seq(nseries))) 
## NULL
function (data = NA, start = 1, end = numeric(), frequency = 1, 
    deltat = 1, ts.eps = getOption("ts.eps"), class = if (nseries > 
        1) c("mts", "ts", "matrix") else "ts", names = if (!is.null(dimnames(data))) colnames(data) else paste("Series", 
        seq(nseries))) 
NULL
## function (data = NA, start = 1, end = numeric(), frequency = 1, 
##     deltat = 1, ts.eps = getOption("ts.eps"), class = if (nseries > 
##         1) c("mts", "ts", "matrix") else "ts", names = if (!is.null(dimnames(data))) colnames(data) else paste("Series", 
##         seq(nseries))) 
## NULL

首先参数中data代表时间序列数据，一个向量或者矩阵，start和end代表时间的范围。最后的频率可以指定时间的单位。例如，如果我们使用月数据，可以设置12代表频率。 本案例中设置季度为频率，所以为4。

tseries <- ts(t, start = c(2000, 1), frequency = 4)
print(tseries)
##            Qtr1       Qtr2       Qtr3       Qtr4
## 2000   7.076670  10.388758  23.910958  14.493559
## 2001  15.905014  28.005455  20.226413   9.144571
## 2002  14.192030  16.880366  29.568573  24.518697
## 2003  25.805400  24.774779  21.109112  38.508392
## 2004  30.484953  14.233680  33.909491  26.690460
## 2005  23.525234  30.474176  25.817969  28.897761
## 2006  30.624725  24.193147  42.864509  39.073612
## 2007  31.033041  48.776704  43.985250  39.934500
## 2008  49.265880  50.146934  50.751068  50.820482
## 2009  50.877424  47.566618  46.858261  47.336703
## 2010  46.137051  50.544579  44.142226  69.182692
## 2011  63.455734  48.138240  54.179806  54.733413
## 2012  64.459756  59.416417  62.773230  61.800173
## 2013  62.699907  73.580216  63.419603  76.615294
## 2014  56.158730  72.092296  69.866980  71.511591
## 2015  73.657476  68.483736  70.667548  66.869972
## 2016  67.497461  78.124700  80.137468  78.371030
## 2017  85.455872  94.350593  77.562782  65.835818
## 2018  90.040170  79.035595  80.183940  93.179000
## 2019  85.006589  79.454976  90.269124  89.027760
## 2020  91.040349  94.696963  90.405380  98.510636
## 2021  93.456594  98.322474 104.677873 101.046270
## 2022  96.718479 108.041653 107.954527 105.838779
## 2023 104.671122  99.604657 114.524567 101.798183
## 2024 122.311331 118.728274 107.350097 102.815054
plot(tseries)

在这种情况下，数据被识别为ts序列，如果ts参数中的data是一个矩阵，那么图中会产生多条时间序列线。

set.seed(123)
seq <- seq(from = 1, to = 100, by = 1) + 10
ts1 <- seq + rnorm(100, sd = 5)
ts2 <- seq + rnorm(100, sd = 12)
ts3 <- seq^2 + rnorm(100, sd = 300)
tsm <- cbind(ts1, ts2, ts3)
tsm <- ts(tsm, start=c(2000, 1), frequency = 4)
plot(tsm)
plot.ts(tsm)

plot 和plot.ts是一样的，在本案例中，序列自动被识别。

args(plot.ts)
## function (x, y = NULL, plot.type = c("multiple", "single"), xy.labels, 
##     xy.lines, panel = lines, nc, yax.flip = FALSE, mar.multi = c(0, 
##         5.1, 0, if (yax.flip) 5.1 else 2.1), oma.multi = c(6, 
##         0, 5, 0), axes = TRUE, ...) 
## NULL

在plot.ts中，参数设置不同于plot 另外，还有一些函数用于数据的提取，比如window()用于提取指定时间范围内的数据。start用于看时间起点，end是终点，frequency是频率，本案例中为4。

tseries_sub <- window(tseries, start=c(2000, 1), end=c(2012,4))
print(tseries_sub)
##           Qtr1      Qtr2      Qtr3      Qtr4
## 2000  7.076670 10.388758 23.910958 14.493559
## 2001 15.905014 28.005455 20.226413  9.144571
## 2002 14.192030 16.880366 29.568573 24.518697
## 2003 25.805400 24.774779 21.109112 38.508392
## 2004 30.484953 14.233680 33.909491 26.690460
## 2005 23.525234 30.474176 25.817969 28.897761
## 2006 30.624725 24.193147 42.864509 39.073612
## 2007 31.033041 48.776704 43.985250 39.934500
## 2008 49.265880 50.146934 50.751068 50.820482
## 2009 50.877424 47.566618 46.858261 47.336703
## 2010 46.137051 50.544579 44.142226 69.182692
## 2011 63.455734 48.138240 54.179806 54.733413
## 2012 64.459756 59.416417 62.773230 61.800173
start(tsm)
## [1] 2000    1
end(tsm)
## [1] 2024    4
frequency(tsm)
## [1] 4

如何处理时间序列数据

tseries_lag1 <- lag(tseries, 1)
head(cbind(tseries, tseries_lag1))
##       tseries tseries_lag1
## [1,]       NA      7.07667
## [2,]  7.07667     10.38876
## [3,] 10.38876     23.91096
## [4,] 23.91096     14.49356
## [5,] 14.49356     15.90501
## [6,] 15.90501     28.00545
tseries_lag1 <- lag(tseries, 3)

lag函数用于对序列进行向前进位的处理，比如向前进1位或者3位。 diff函数用于提取时间序列的差分

tseries_diff1 <- diff(tseries, lag = 1) # lag设置差分的位数
tm <- cbind(tseries, tseries_diff1) 
head(tm)
##       tseries tseries_diff1
## [1,]  7.07667            NA
## [2,] 10.38876      3.312087
## [3,] 23.91096     13.522201
## [4,] 14.49356     -9.417399
## [5,] 15.90501      1.411455
## [6,] 28.00545     12.100441
plot.ts(tm)

或者差分2位，diff函数有效的去除了趋势成分，保留静态的噪声成分。

tseries_diff2 <- diff(tseries, lag = 2)
tm <- cbind(tseries, tseries_diff2)
head(tm)
##       tseries tseries_diff2
## [1,]  7.07667            NA
## [2,] 10.38876            NA
## [3,] 23.91096     16.834288
## [4,] 14.49356      4.104801
## [5,] 15.90501     -8.005944
## [6,] 28.00545     13.511896
plot.ts(tm)

有时候时间序列数据的方差会越来越大

trend <- ts(seq(from = 10, to = 110))
cycle <- ts(sin(trend)) * 0.2 * trend
tseries_h <- trend + cycle
plot.ts(tseries_h)

方差越来越大会导致heteroskedasticity，违背了线性回归的基本假设，所以通过log方法对数据进行转化

tseries_log <- log(tseries_h)
tm <-cbind(tseries_h, tseries_log)
plot.ts(tm)

另一种去除非恒定方差的方法是box-cox转化。

library("forecast")
plot.ts(BoxCox(tseries_h, lambda = 0.5))

box-cox变换中lambda的值并不能完全去除掉heteroskedasticity问题，我们可以设定不同的lambda值，以寻找到最合适的

lambda <- BoxCox.lambda(tseries_h)
print(lambda)
## [1] 0.05527724
plot.ts(BoxCox(tseries_h, lambda = lambda))

对于时间序列，另一个常见的计算方法是看一个时间的数据相对于前一个时间数据变化的程度。

tseries_pch <- tseries / lag(tseries, -1) - 1
head(cbind(tseries, tseries_pch))
##          tseries tseries_pch
## 2000 Q1  7.07667          NA
## 2000 Q2 10.38876  0.46802901
## 2000 Q3 23.91096  1.30161865
## 2000 Q4 14.49356 -0.39385287
## 2001 Q1 15.90501  0.09738501
## 2001 Q2 28.00545  0.76079409
# 根据上面写一个函数
pch <- function(data, lag = 1) {
    # argument verification
    if (!is.ts(data)) stop("data must be of type ts") # 判别函数
    if (!is.numeric(lag)) stop("lag must be of type numeric") # 判别lag函数
    # return percent change
    data / lag(data, -lag) - 1
}
head(cbind(tseries, pch(tseries)))
##          tseries pch(tseries)
## 2000 Q1  7.07667           NA
## 2000 Q2 10.38876   0.46802901
## 2000 Q3 23.91096   1.30161865
## 2000 Q4 14.49356  -0.39385287
## 2001 Q1 15.90501   0.09738501
## 2001 Q2 28.00545   0.76079409

有了这个函数，我们可以看每年同时期的数据变化，所以设置lag=4

tseries_pchya <- pch(tseries, lag=4)
tseries_dlog <- ts(diff(log(tseries)), start = c(2000, 1), frequency = 4)
plot.ts(cbind(tseries, tseries_dlog))

plot.ts(cbind(pch(tseries), tseries_dlog))

本案例中diff和pch函数产生类似的图。

时间序列另一个方案，移动平均moving average，对于具有高变化性的数据，移动平均可以看出数据的趋势

tseries_lf5 <- filter(tseries, filter = rep(1/5, 5), sides = 1)
plot.ts(cbind(tseries, tseries_lf5), plot.type = 'single', col = c('black', 'red'))

或者使用一个SMA函数

library(TTR)
tseries_ma5 <- SMA(tseries, n = 5)
plot(tseries_ma5)

tseries_ma5fore <- ma(tseries, order = 5) # 同上

item.title: merge two table
item.description:
The question is how to merge two tables, it is easy to use merge. However, it is not easy to merge because the two table have different sample sizes and we want to keep all of them.

Table 1: Some names not in table 2
name plot1
name_g 1
name_l 2
name_y 3
name_c 4
name_p 5
name_k 6
name_e 7
name_q 8
name_b 9
name_n 10
name_m 11
name_u 12
name_z 13
name_w 14
name_d 15
Table 1: Some names not in table 1
name plot2
name_y 1
name_j 2
name_m 3
name_a 4
name_p 5
name_o 6
name_q 7
name_f 8
name_i 9
name_n 10

Now we have problems, some names exist in table 1 but not in table 2, and vice verse.

library(reshape2)
t_1_m <- melt(t_1,value.name = "plot")
t_2_m <- melt(t_2,value.name = "plot")
t_3_m <- rbind(t_1_m, t_2_m)
Table 2: we rbind the two tables
name variable plot
name_g plot1 1
name_l plot1 2
name_y plot1 3
name_c plot1 4
name_p plot1 5
name_k plot1 6
name_e plot1 7
name_q plot1 8
name_b plot1 9
name_n plot1 10
name_m plot1 11
name_u plot1 12
name_z plot1 13
name_w plot1 14
name_d plot1 15
name_y plot2 1
name_j plot2 2
name_m plot2 3
name_a plot2 4
name_p plot2 5
name_o plot2 6
name_q plot2 7
name_f plot2 8
name_i plot2 9
name_n plot2 10

merge does not match our aim, so we just bind the table and creat new tables for the samples which not occur Table 1 and Table 2. Next step, we find the names not in both tables and creat new variables.

n1 <- t_3_m[t_3_m$name %in% name_1[in_1_notin2],]$name
l1 <- length(n1)
t1 <- data.frame("name"=n1, "variable" = c(rep("plot2",l1)),"plot" =rep(0,l1))

n2 <- t_3_m[t_3_m$name %in% name_2[in_2_notin1],]$name
l2 <- length(n2)
t2 <- data.frame("name"=n2, "variable" = c(rep("plot1",l2)), "plot"=rep(0,l2))

tab.f <- rbind(t_3_m,t1,t2)
Table 3: Finally, here we go
name variable plot
name_g plot1 1
name_l plot1 2
name_y plot1 3
name_c plot1 4
name_p plot1 5
name_k plot1 6
name_e plot1 7
name_q plot1 8
name_b plot1 9
name_n plot1 10
name_m plot1 11
name_u plot1 12
name_z plot1 13
name_w plot1 14
name_d plot1 15
name_y plot2 1
name_j plot2 2
name_m plot2 3
name_a plot2 4
name_p plot2 5
name_o plot2 6
name_q plot2 7
name_f plot2 8
name_i plot2 9
name_n plot2 10
name_g plot2 0
name_l plot2 0
name_c plot2 0
name_k plot2 0
name_e plot2 0
name_b plot2 0
name_u plot2 0
name_z plot2 0
name_w plot2 0
name_d plot2 0
name_j plot1 0
name_a plot1 0
name_o plot1 0
name_f plot1 0
name_i plot1 0

And finally, here we go!

item.title: How many remnant gibbon populations are left on Hainan? Testing the use of local ecological knowledge to detect cryptic threatened primates
Example Talk
item.description: Embed your slides or video here using shortcodes. Further details can easily be added using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.

item.title: Academic: the website designer for Hugo
item.description:
Academic is a framework to help you create a beautiful website quickly. Perfect for personal sites, blogs, or business/project sites. Check out the latest demo of what you’ll get in less than 10 minutes. Then head on over to the Quick Start guide or take a look at the Release Notes.

Key features:

  • Easily manage various content including homepage, blog posts, publications, talks, and projects
  • Extensible via color themes and widgets/plugins
  • Write in Markdown for easy formatting and code highlighting, with LaTeX for mathematical expressions
  • Social/academic network linking, Google Analytics, and Disqus comments
  • Responsive and mobile friendly
  • Simple and refreshing one page design
  • Multilingual and easy to customize

Color Themes

Academic is available in different color themes and font themes.

Install

You can choose from one of the following four methods to install:

  • one-click install using your web browser (recommended)
  • install on your computer using Git with the Command Prompt/Terminal app
  • install on your computer by downloading the ZIP files
  • install on your computer with RStudio

Quick install using your web browser

  1. Install Academic with Netlify
    • Netlify will provide you with a customizable URL to access your new site
  2. On GitHub, go to your newly created academic-kickstart repository and edit config.toml to personalize your site. Shortly after saving the file, your site will automatically update
  3. Read the Quick Start Guide to learn how to add Markdown content. For inspiration, refer to the Markdown content which powers the Demo

Install with Git

Prerequisites:

  • Download and install Git
  • Download and install Hugo

  1. Fork the Academic Kickstart repository and clone your fork with Git:

    git clone https://github.com/sourcethemes/academic-kickstart.git My_Website

    Note that if you forked Academic Kickstart, the above command should be edited to clone your fork, i.e. replace sourcethemes with your GitHub username.

  2. Initialize the theme:

    cd My_Website
git submodule update --init --recursive

Install with ZIP

  1. Download and extract Academic Kickstart
  2. Download and extract the Academic theme to the themes/academic/ folder from the above step

Install with RStudio

View the guide to installing Academic with RStudio

Quick start

  1. If you installed on your computer, view your new website by running the following command:

    hugo server

    Now visit localhost:1313 and your new Academic powered website will appear. Otherwise, if using Netlify, they will provide you with your URL.

  2. Read the Quick Start Guide to learn how to add Markdown content, customize your site, and deploy it. For inspiration, refer to the Markdown content which powers the Demo

  3. Build your site by running the hugo command. Then host it for free using Github Pages or Netlify (refer to the first installation method). Alternatively, copy the generated public/ directory (by FTP, Rsync, etc.) to your production web server (such as a university’s hosting service).

Updating

Feel free to star the project on Github to help keep track of updates and check out the release notes prior to updating your site.

Before updating the framework, it is recommended to make a backup of your entire website directory (or at least your themes/academic directory) and record your current version number.

By default, Academic is installed as a Git submodule which can be updated by running the following command:

git submodule update --remote --merge

Check out the update guide for full instructions and alternative methods.

Feedback & Contributing

Please use the issue tracker to let me know about any bugs or feature requests, or alternatively make a pull request.

For support, head over to the Hugo discussion forum.

License

Copyright 2016-present George Cushen.

Released under the MIT license.

item.title: Proximity association in polygynous western black crested gibbons (Nomascus concolor jingdongensis): network structure and seasonality
